title: Thörle 2016 Saulheimer Hölle Spätlese Riesling (Rheinhessen)
description: An undertone of crushed minerals lends elegance to concentrated yellow peach, apple and grapefruit in this plump, sweet-tart spätlese. While light in body, there's a pleasant creaminess of texture, balanced by bracing lemon-lime acidity.

title: Trentadue 2015 La Storia Petite Sirah (Alexander Valley)
description: Softly textured tannins surround a hefty full-bodied plushness of plummy cobbler, blueberry and dark chocolate in this well-made, robust and rich wine. Caramel and mocha appear on the lengthy finish.

title: Whitehall Lane 2014 Leonardini Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
description: Tomato leaf, dried herb and cedar are offered on the nose and palate of this wine, which is well-integrated in oak. Full-bodied and grippy, it's youthful in structure, with final notes of pencil shavings and focused acidity.

title: A.A. Badenhorst Family Wines 2015 Secateurs Red (Swartland)
description: This Shiraz-based blend, with 21% Cinsault and 8% Grenache, offers earthy notes of fresh mint, white pepper and herbal fynbos, all spicing up the red cherry and raspberry fruit core. A delicate whiff of sweet smoke is seductive, while the palate offers more earthy notes of tilled earth and currant leaf that carry through to the finish. Fine but structured tannins lend a velvety texture. Drink now–2020.

title: Anam Cara 2015 Nicholas Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
description: This bursts forth with spicy cranberry and cherry fruit. It's a bright vivacious wine, fruit-driven and lightly peppery. Thoughts of roast turkey inevitably come to mind—save a bottle for next Thanksgiving.

title: Antica Fratta 2013 Essence Brut  (Franciacorta)
description: Aromas of bread crust, ripe orchard fruit and citrus zest waft out of the glass. The vibrant palate doles out Rennet apple, pear and tangerine alongside fresh acidity and a lively perlage. A hint of hazelnut closes the finish.

title: Archium 2015 Dissident G-S-M (Santa Barbara County)
description: Very light in the glass, this blend of 43% Grenache, 36% Syrah and 21% Mourvèdre offers fairly simple yet likable berry aromas. There's a surprising amount of textural grip to the palate and loads of earthy minerality, with hibiscus, red plum and gravel flavors proving more complex than the nose implied.

title: Avignonesi 2013 Grandi Annate  (Vino Nobile di Montepulciano)
description: Dark-skinned berry, forest floor, new oak and exotic spice aromas are front and center. The dense palate offers dried black cherry, cranberry, oak, vanilla and coconut framed in tightly knit, fine-grained tannins. Drink 2019–2028.

title: Château le Manoir 2015 Cuvée Prestige  (Lalande de Pomerol)
description: As befits a wine that is part of this Pomerol satellite appellation, this is almost entirely Merlot. New-wood aging adds a minty character and dark-coffee flavor. Firm tannins, bold black fruits and balanced acidity all make their mark in this potentially opulent wine. Drink from 2021.

title: Château Mayne Vieil 2015  Fronsac
description: Merlot gives this wine its richness and density. Partial oak aging adds to the ripe, smooth texture. Tannins, layers of spice and bold red fruits add concentration as well as juicy acidity. Drink from 2019.

title: Clos du Marquis 2015 La Petite Marquise  (Saint-Julien)
description: The Clos du Marquis, formerly the second wine of Léoville las Cases, now has its own second wine that comes from young vines. It is a rich, juicy and succulent wine, bright with acidity and black-currant flavors. The firm tannins are in the background, meaning this wine will age relatively quickly. Drink from 2021.

title: Clos la Bohème 2015  Haut-Médoc
description: This wine comes from a seven-acre property in the south of the Haut-Médoc. Well textured, ripe with black fruits and firm with tannins, this is quite an enjoyable wine. It will develop into a beautiful, rich wine. Drink from 2024.

title: De Ponte Cellars 2010 Dundee Hills Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
description: The winery has re-released this wine, providing a close look at how a properly-stored Pinot can age. In this instance, quite gracefully, and now drinking at a pleasing balance between youthful fruit and the autumnal flavors of older wines. Spicy cranberries and flavors of mellow baked berries and cherries come along with a streak of cola. It should drink well for another four or five years.

title: Descendant 2013 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))
description: An extremely pale, orange-tinged color belies an aromatically expressive wine, with appealing notes of white pepper, wild raspberry and herb. The palate is sumptuous yet light in feel, with achingly pure fruit flavors. This wine is all about elegance—perhaps too much for some tastes. But for those seeking the variety's delicate side, look no further. Drink now.

title: Domaine Bott-Geyl 2013 Galets Oligocène Pinot Noir (Alsace)
description: The nose is a subtle combination of the merest touch of cinnamon and red cherry. The palate is light and firm, with ample freshness and a lovely impression of tart fruit. This is understated and fresh in a savory style.

title: Château Cos d'Estournel 2015 Cos d'Estournel Blanc  (Bordeaux Blanc)
description: Fruity, herbal and with crisp acidity, this bright wine is full of grapefruit, apples and green plums. The mineral tang will give this wine shape as it matures. Drink from 2019.

title: Château de Lavagnac 2015 La Grande Dame de Château Lavagnac  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
description: This oak-aged wine is the top cuvée from this estate. The wood is prominent at this young stage, although there is also plenty of black fruit. The wood, as it integrates, will enrich this ripe wine, bringing out the firm structure. The wine needs to age. Drink from 2020.
designation: La Grande Dame de Château Lavagnac

title: Château Dillon 2015  Haut-Médoc
description: This estate is part of the Bordeaux winemaking school, giving students the chance to put their hands in the vineyard. The wine, rich and packed with fruit, is exemplary. It is full of berry fruits, generous and with fine, ripe tannins. It will age well. Drink from 2022.

title: Château Donissan 2015  Listrac-Médoc
description: This wine comes from a small estate for the Médoc (25 acres). With good balance between the rich fruits and tannins, it has a juicy character that is already delicious. However, the tannins will soften and fill out as the wine matures. This wine will drink best from 2021.

title: Château du Moulin Rouge 2015  Haut-Médoc
description: Set in the heart of Haut-Médoc and close to the 18th-century fortress designed to stop the British attacking through the Gironde estuary (they never tried), this estate has made a firm, tannic wine that has great black fruits and a rich potential. Drink from 2022.

title: Château Grivière 2015  Médoc
description: Coming from up to 60 different parcels spread across 100 acres, this wine is impressive in its richness and fine, dusty tannins. It is dense, concentrated and sure to age well. Drink from 2023.

title: Barons 2016 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
description: Fruit for this wine comes from Block Two of Gamache Vineyard. Aged in a mixture of stainless steel and French oak (30% new), the aromas offer notes of hay, corn silk, lees and cut yellow apple along with peach. Flavors are broad and leesy, gliding on the finish.

title: Benziger 2015 Signaterra West Rows Sangiacomo Vineyard Chardonnay (Los Carneros)
description: Reduced, with a spritzy underbelly of acidity, this wine lands fresh and vibrant in dried herb and green apple, with a medium-bodied ripeness and use of oak.

title: Bogle 2014 Phantom Red (California)
description: This is not your average red blend, because it has outstanding concentration, multiple layers of dark-fruit flavors and cedary, spicy nuances as well as a richly tannic texture. It will pair well with a grilled lamb chop, and should improve with a little age. Best after 2020.

title: Brander 2016 Vino Joven Cabernet Sauvignon (Los Olivos District)
description: There's a growing trend of making red wines fresh, fun and ready to glug, and this bottling, which spent just six months in French oak, fits the movement perfectly. Bright aromas of rose, lilac, smashed black raspberry, candied plum skin and pepper dust dive into a zippy palate of cherry fruit, baking spice and dried ginger. Chill and drink on a hot day.

title: Cardwell Hill 2014 Old Vines Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
description: From vines planted in 1983, this delivers old-vine complexity at a budget price. It's big, broad and fruity, with a range of candied strawberry, raspberry, cherry flavors. Those old vines ramp up the texture and add length as well.

title: Clos la Madeleine 2017 Barrel Sample  (Saint-Émilion)
description: 89–91. Barrel Sample. This is generous and rich in character—ripe with black plum. From a six-acre property, it is rounded, spicy and likely to remain warm and full.

title: Château Doisy-Daëne 2017 Barrel Sample  (Barsac)
description: 89–91. Barrel Sample. Fresh and crisp, this is a light wine, shining with acidity, citrus and spice. Lemon juice and crisp quince flavors are backed by light botrytis character. Drink from 2021.

title: Château d'Agassac 2017 Barrel Sample  (Haut-Médoc)
description: 89–91. Barrel Sample. Bright and fruity, this is a light, crisp wine. Its black currant fruits and attractive acidity give it a poised feel and the possibility of early drinking. It should be ready from 2021.

title: Château Labégorce Margaux 2017 Barrel Sample  (Margaux)
description: 89–91. Barrel Sample. High amounts of wood mark this wine from the start, giving a more toasty impression than fruity. It is austere, only hinting at the fruit that should develop. WHold until 2024.
